commit_message:
Modify "/v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/resources" API detail

This patch modifies api-ref[1] for the following REST call detail,
/v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/resources
It explains for /v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/resources,
the canonical URL will only be returned for non-deleted stacks,
and the /v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/{stack_id}/resources
form should be used to fetch the resource list of deleted stacks.

[1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-orchestration-v1.html

Closes-Bug: #1460744

Change-Id: I7024193aafe7e7c90a7ac165b23431f469ce6d69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/60/187860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: stack. The canonical URL will only be returned for non-deleted stacks, and the /v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/{stack_id}/resources form should be used to fetch the resource list of deleted stacks.

commit_message:
Prevent multiple form submission on table row actions

This disables any table row actions that do a form submit after an
action is taken and the form is being submitted. It also changes the
cursor to make it clear an action is taking place.

Closes-Bug: #1433849
Change-Id: I004f0ae43e5201eba30ff38a34be680416407fbc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/04/187604/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: submit_in_progress = $table.closest('form').attr('data-submitted'), // Do not update this row if the action column is expanded or the form // is in the process of being submitted. If we update the row while the // form is still submitting any disabled action buttons would potentially // be enabled again, allowing for multiple form submits. if ($rows_to_update.find('.actions_column .btn-group.open').length || submit_in_progress) { }, disable_actions_on_submit: function($form) { // This applies changes to the table form when a user takes an action that // submits the form. It relies on the form being re-rendered after the // submit is completed to remove these changes. $form = $form || $(".table_wrapper > form"); $form.on("submit", function () { // Add the 'submitted' flag to the form so the row update interval knows // not to update the row and therefore re-enable the actions that we are // disabling here. $(this).attr('data-submitted', 'true'); // Disable row action buttons. This prevents multiple form submission. $(this).find('td.actions_column button[type="submit"]').addClass("disabled"); // Use CSS to update the cursor so it's very clear that an action is // in progress. $(this).addClass('wait'); }); horizon.datatables.disable_actions_on_submit(); horizon.modals.addModalInitFunction(horizon.datatables.disable_actions_on_submit); horizon.datatables.disable_actions_on_submit($(tab).find(".table_wrapper > form"));
deleted_lines: // Do not update this row if the action column is expanded if ($rows_to_update.find('.actions_column .btn-group.open').length) {

commit_message:
Fix wrong assumption of endpoint names

This change comes to fix the wrong assumption that br-storage
and br-mgmt are the storage and management endpoint names,
and instead, use the value of the roles dictionary.

Closes-Bug: #1462005

Change-Id: I53c20fffc7b7a126d448640d23f110751b683abb

commit_message:
Hidden HOST in instance overview page for normal user

If the logined user is normal user, the instance overview page
will always show "HOST: -". There is no need show them for normal
users, it may cause some safety problem.

Closes-Bug: 1417849
Change-Id: Ib51bb05822fe910e97f73af56a8d6856764f7653

subject: ARP spoofing patch: Ebtables manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-20 02:07:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4a7f59fa941ec6834a2d7110f4247a6dd232f983', 'message': "ARP spoofing patch: Ebtables manager

ARP cache poisoning is not actually prevented by the firewall
driver 'iptables_firewall'. We are adding the use of the ebtables
command - with a corresponding ebtables-driver - in order to create
Ethernet frame filtering rules, which prevent the sending of ARP
cache poisoning frames.

The complete patch is broken into smaller patch sets for easier review.

This patch set here includes the ebtables manager class.

Note:
    This commit is based greatly on an original, now abandoned patch,
    presented for review here:

        https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70067/

Full spec can be found here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/129090/

Change-Id: Ic115eeb59cbacdafb85296d435322ea8b8cc99d6
Implements: blueprint arp-spoof-patch-ebtables

commit_message:
ARP spoofing patch: Ebtables manager

ARP cache poisoning is not actually prevented by the firewall
driver 'iptables_firewall'. We are adding the use of the ebtables
command - with a corresponding ebtables-driver - in order to create
Ethernet frame filtering rules, which prevent the sending of ARP
cache poisoning frames.

The complete patch is broken into smaller patch sets for easier review.

This patch set here includes the ebtables manager class.

Note:
    This commit is based greatly on an original, now abandoned patch,
    presented for review here:

        https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70067/

Full spec can be found here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/129090/

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: Ic115eeb59cbacdafb85296d435322ea8b8cc99d6
Implements: blueprint arp-spoof-patch-ebtables
Related-Bug: 1274034
Co-Authored-By: jbrendel <jbrendel@cisco.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/34/157634/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

from neutron.agent.linux.ebtables_manager import EbtablesManagerdef fake_execute(*args, **kwargs): """Fake command runner for testing purposes.""" arg_list = args[0] table_name = arg_list[2] if "--atomic-file" in arg_list: lines = ("Bridge table: filter
" "Bridge chain: INPUT, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT
" "Bridge chain: FORWARD, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT
" "Bridge chain: OUTPUT, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT
") return lines elif "--Lc" in arg_list: # Caller wants to see traffic counters out = ["Bridge table: %s" % table_name, "", "Bridge chain: Some stuff", "-j CONTINUE , pcnt = 123 -- bcnt = 1230"] return "
".join(out) class EbtablesManagerTestCase(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(EbtablesManagerTestCase, self).setUp() ChainName.binary_name = classmethod(lambda c: "binary") self.call_sequence = list() def call_sequence_keeper(*args, **kwargs): # Simple helper to keep track of the fake calls to the ebtables # utility. self.call_sequence.append(args[0]) return fake_execute(*args, **kwargs) self.em = EbtablesManager(_execute=call_sequence_keeper) def _table_compare(self, should): """Compare ebtables management results.""" self.assertEqual(len(should), len(self.em._tables)) self.assertEqual(sorted(should.keys()), sorted(self.em._tables.keys())) for tname, t in self.em._tables.items(): self.assertEqual(should[tname], [str(r) for r in t.rules]) def _call_sequence_compare(self, should): """Compare the recent call-sequence to ebtables.""" # Each call sequence contains the full ebtable command, but the really # interesting bits start at the 5th element... current_call_sequence = [r[5:] for r in self.call_sequence] self.assertEqual(should, current_call_sequence) def test_basics(self): # There should be some basic rules right after initialization should = { "filter": [ "-A INPUT -j binary-INPUT", "-A OUTPUT -j binary-OUTPUT", "-A FORWARD -j binary-FORWARD" ], "broute": [ "-A BROUTING -j binary-BROUTING", ], "nat": [ "-A PREROUTING -j binary-PREROUTING", "-A OUTPUT -j binary-OUTPUT", "-A POSTROUTING -j binary-POSTROUTING", ] } self._table_compare(should) self.assertEqual(set(['OUTPUT', 'PREROUTING', 'POSTROUTING']), self.em.get_table("nat").chains) self.assertEqual(should["nat"], [str(r) for r in self.em.get_table("nat").rules]) def test_remove_tables(self): self.em.remove_table("broute") self.em.remove_table("nat") should = { "filter": [ "-A INPUT -j binary-INPUT", "-A OUTPUT -j binary-OUTPUT", "-A FORWARD -j binary-FORWARD" ] } self._table_compare(should) def test_get_counters(self): # Our fake execute returns some counters acc = self.em.get_traffic_counters("FORWARD") self.assertEqual({"pkts": 123, "bytes": 1230}, acc) def test_adding_rules(self): self.em.defer_apply_off() self.em.remove_table("broute") self.em.remove_table("nat") table = self.em.get_table("filter") table.add_rule("FORWARD", "some random rule") self.call_sequence = list() self.em.apply() should = [ ['-L', '--Lc'], ['--atomic-init'], ['-P', 'INPUT', 'ACCEPT'], ['-P', 'FORWARD', 'ACCEPT'], ['-P', 'OUTPUT', 'ACCEPT'], ['-N', 'binary-FORWARD', '-P', 'ACCEPT'], ['-N', 'binary-INPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT'], ['-N', 'binary-OUTPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT'], ['-A', 'INPUT', '-j', 'binary-INPUT'], ['-A', 'OUTPUT', '-j', 'binary-OUTPUT'], ['-A', 'FORWARD', '-j', 'binary-FORWARD'], ['-A', 'binary-FORWARD', 'some', 'random', 'rule'], ['--atomic-commit'] ] self._call_sequence_compare(should) def test_removing_chains(self): self.em.defer_apply_off() self.em.remove_table("broute") self.em.remove_table("nat") # Remove the wrapped "binary-FORWARD" chain self.em.get_table("filter").ensure_remove_chain("FORWARD") self.call_sequence = list() self.em.apply() should = [ ['-L', '--Lc'], ['--atomic-init'], ['-P', 'INPUT', 'ACCEPT'], ['-P', 'FORWARD', 'ACCEPT'], ['-P', 'OUTPUT', 'ACCEPT'], ['-N', 'binary-INPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT'], ['-N', 'binary-OUTPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT'], ['-A', 'INPUT', '-j', 'binary-INPUT'], ['-A', 'OUTPUT', '-j', 'binary-OUTPUT'], ['--atomic-commit'] ] self._call_sequence_compare(should)

subject: Add a new lbaas agent Scheduler, LeastPoolAgentScheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-09 04:34:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/44f8e02b0a82092d1154b67ef43193df37d83c00', 'message': 'Added a new Scheduler, LeastPoolAgentScheduler, which assigns a
pool to an lbaas-agent that has the least number of pools. When
there are multiple lbaas-agents on multiple nodes, pools will be
evenly distributed over the agents. Thus this scheduler helps
the scalability of lbaas-agents serving large number of pools.
At the moment only available lbaas-agent scheduler is ChanceScheduler.

Change-Id: I0b920a8bb5b2918dd5f47ef2a81d3009896af47d

commit_message:
Add a new lbaas agent Scheduler, LeastPoolAgentScheduler

LeastPoolAgentScheduler assigns a pool to an lbaas-agent
with the least number of pools. When there are multiple
lbaas-agents on multiple nodes, pools will be evenly
distributed over the agents. Thus this scheduler helps
the scalability of lbaas-agents serving large number of pools.
At the moment only available lbaas-agent scheduler is ChanceScheduler.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0b920a8bb5b2918dd5f47ef2a81d3009896af47d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/09/181609/26 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def num_of_pools_on_lbaas_agent(self, context, id): tmp = self.list_pools_on_lbaas_agent(context, id) return len(tmp['pools']) class ScheduleChooser(object): def schedule(self, plugin, context, pool, device_driver, scheduler_type = "ChanceScheduler"): if scheduler_type == "ChanceScheduler": """Allocate a loadbalancer agent for a vip in a random way.""" chosen_agent = random.choice(candidates) elif scheduler_type == "LeastPoolAgentScheduler": """Pick an agent with least number of pools from candidates""" current_min_pool_num = -1 tmp_pool_num = 0 for tmp_agent in candidates: tmp_pool_num = plugin.num_of_pools_on_lbaas_agent(context, tmp_agent['id']) if (current_min_pool_num == -1) or (current_min_pool_num > tmp_pool_num): current_min_pool_num = tmp_pool_num chosen_agent = tmp_agent else: return class ChanceScheduler(ScheduleChooser): def schedule(self, plugin, context, pool, device_driver): return super(ChanceScheduler, self).schedule(plugin, context, pool, device_driver, "ChanceScheduler") class LeastPoolAgentScheduler(ScheduleChooser): def schedule(self, plugin, context, pool, device_driver): return super(LeastPoolAgentScheduler, self).schedule(plugin, context, pool, device_driver, "LeastPoolAgentScheduler")
deleted_lines: class ChanceScheduler(object): """Allocate a loadbalancer agent for a vip in a random way.""" def schedule(self, plugin, context, pool, device_driver): chosen_agent = random.choice(candidates)

commit_message:
ARP spoofing patch: Ebtables/iptables integration

ARP cache poisoning is not actually prevented by the firewall
driver 'iptables_firewall'. We are adding the use of the ebtables
command - with a corresponding ebtables-driver - in order to create
Ethernet frame filtering rules, which prevent the sending of ARP
cache poisoning frames.

The complete patch is broken into smaller patch sets for easier review.

This patch set here includes the integration between iptables and the ebtables
manager.

Note:
    This commit is based greatly on an original, now abandoned patch,
    presented for review here:

        https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70067/

Full spec can be found here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/129090/

Change-Id: Ibc6d3d520c1383cf7e00f4bdeb7853a41ac4b14b
Implements: blueprint arp-spoof-patch-ebtables
Closes-Bug: 1274034
Co-Authored-By: jbrendel <jbrendel@cisco.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/91/158491/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012, Nachi Ueno, NTT MCL, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import netaddr from oslo_config import cfg from neutron.agent.linux import ebtables_manager from neutron.agent.linux import table_defs as td class NWFilterFirewall(object): """ This class implements a network filtering mechanism by using ebtables. All ports get a base filter applied. This filter provides some basic security such as protection against MAC spoofing, IP spoofing, and ARP spoofing. """ def __init__(self, root_helper=None, namespace=None, default_chain='FORWARD', _execute=None): self.default_chain = default_chain if not root_helper: root_helper = cfg.CONF.AGENT.root_helper self.ebtables = ebtables_manager.EbtablesManager( root_helper=root_helper, namespace=namespace, prefix_chain='neutron-nwfilter', _execute=_execute) with ebtables_manager.EbtablesManagerTransaction(self.ebtables): self.ebtables.remove_table('nat') self.ebtables.remove_table('broute') table = self.ebtables.get_table('filter') self.fallback_chain_name = self._add_fallback_chain(table) def setup_basic_filtering(self, port_id, device, mac_ip_pairs): if port_id is None or device is None: return if mac_ip_pairs is None or mac_ip_pairs[0] is None: return table = self.ebtables.get_table('filter') # Set rules and chains for the device self._setup_device_chains(table, port_id, device) # Set anti ARP spoofing arp_rules = self._setup_arp_antispoofing(mac_ip_pairs) arp_rules += ['-j $%s' % self.fallback_chain_name] arp_chain_name = self._port_chain_name( td.SPOOFING_CHAIN_NAME_PREFIX_ARP + port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) self._set_chain_and_rules(table, arp_chain_name, arp_rules) rules = ['-p arp -j $%s' % arp_chain_name] self._set_rules_for_device(table, port_id, rules, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) # Set the MAC/IP anti spoofing rules and allow DHCP traffic # NOTE(ethuleau): more? # - IPv6 neighbor discovery reflection filter # - IPv6 RA advertisement filter # - ... # Should we implement _accept_inbound_icmpv6 (line 374) method here? ip_rules = self._allow_dhcp_request() ip_rules += self._drop_dhcp_offer_rule() ip_rules += self._setup_mac_ip_antispoofing(mac_ip_pairs) ip_rules += ['-j $%s' % self.fallback_chain_name] ip_chain_name = self._port_chain_name( td.SPOOFING_CHAIN_NAME_PREFIX_IP + port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) self._set_chain_and_rules(table, ip_chain_name, ip_rules) jump_rules = ['-p IPv4 -j $%s' % ip_chain_name] jump_rules += ['-p IPv6 -j $%s' % ip_chain_name] self._set_rules_for_device(table, port_id, jump_rules, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) self.ebtables.apply() def unfilter_instance(self, port_id): if port_id is None: return table = self.ebtables.get_table('filter') chain_name = self._port_chain_name(port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) table.ensure_remove_chain(chain_name) arp_chain_name = self._port_chain_name( td.SPOOFING_CHAIN_NAME_PREFIX_ARP + port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) table.ensure_remove_chain(arp_chain_name) ip_chain_name = self._port_chain_name( td.SPOOFING_CHAIN_NAME_PREFIX_IP + port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) table.ensure_remove_chain(ip_chain_name) self.ebtables.apply() def defer_apply_on(self): self.ebtables.defer_apply_on() def defer_apply_off(self): self.ebtables.defer_apply_off() def _setup_device_chains(self, table, port_id, device): # Add chain and jump to all incoming from the device chain_name = self._port_chain_name(port_id, td.INGRESS_DIRECTION) table.add_chain(chain_name) if device != "*": rule = '--in-interface %s ' % device else: rule = '' rule += '-j $%s' % chain_name table.add_rule(self.default_chain, rule, top=True) #table.add_rule('OUTPUT', rule, top=True) # NOTE(ethuleau): Do we need to apply some filters on traffic going to # the device (eg. DHCP request of neighbors)? def _allow_dhcp_request(self): # Note(ethuleau): The sg mixin already set default provider sg to # protect DHCP traffic (neutron/db/securitygroups_rpc_base.py, line # 254). # Only incoming DHCP server traffic is authorize from DHCP # servers IP and DHCP server traffic is drop if it's coming from the # VM. Should we support that in the NWFilterFirewall class? rules = [] for proto in ['udp', 'tcp']: # NOTE(ethuleau): we limit DHCP request to not overload DHCP agents # One request per second with a burst of 5 (default value) is # enough? rules += ['-p IPv4 --ip-proto %s --ip-sport 68 --ip-dport 67 ' '--limit 1/s -j ACCEPT' % proto] return rules def _drop_dhcp_offer_rule(self): rules = [] for proto in ['udp', 'tcp']: rules += ['-p IPv4 --ip-proto %s --ip-sport 67 --ip-dport 68 ' '-j DROP' % proto] return rules def _setup_mac_ip_antispoofing(self, mac_ip_pairs): rules = [] for mac, ip in mac_ip_pairs: if ip is None: rules += ['-p %s -j RETURN' % mac] else: rules += ['-s %s -p %s --ip-source %s -j RETURN' % (mac, self._get_ip_protocol(ip), ip)] return rules def _setup_arp_antispoofing(self, mac_ip_pairs): rules = [] for mac, ip in mac_ip_pairs: if ip is not None: rules += [('-p arp --arp-opcode 2 --arp-mac-src %s ' '--arp-ip-src %s -j RETURN') % (mac, ip)] rules += ['-p ARP --arp-op Request -j ACCEPT'] return rules def _add_fallback_chain(self, table): table.add_chain('spoofing-fallback') table.add_rule('spoofing-fallback', '-j DROP') return self.ebtables.get_chain_name('spoofing-fallback') def _port_chain_name(self, port_id, direction): return self.ebtables.get_chain_name( '%s%s' % (td.CHAIN_NAME_PREFIX[direction], port_id)) def _get_ip_protocol(self, ip_address): if netaddr.IPNetwork(ip_address).version == 4: return 'IPv4' else: return 'IPv6' def _set_rules_for_device(self, table, port_id, rules, direction): chain_name = self._port_chain_name(port_id, direction) for rule in rules: table.add_rule(chain_name, rule) def _set_chain_and_rules(self, table, chain_name, rules): table.add_chain(chain_name) for rule in rules: table.add_rule(chain_name, rule)

commit_message:
Delete period from select option in LiveMigrateForm

It is unusual to have a period at the end of select options

commit_message:
Add support for ceilometer-polling agent

Add ability to use new ceilometer-polling agent
instead of ceilometer-central, ceilometer-compute or
ceilometer-ipmi. Specify central_namespace, compute_namespace
and ipmi_namespace parameters to set namespaces

Change-Id: I066f601a5234cb689c98e8eea2b5790bdaa5b8b5

added_lines: $agent_polling_package_name = 'openstack-ceilometer-polling' $agent_polling_service_name = 'openstack-ceilometer-polling' $ceilometer_polling_default = '/etc/sysconfig/openstack-ceilometer-polling' $agent_polling_package_name = 'ceilometer-polling' $agent_polling_service_name = 'ceilometer-polling' $ceilometer_polling_default = '/etc/default/ceilometer-polling'

commit_message:
Improve unittests for angular charts

Currently our angular charts unit tests are a bit incomplete.

charts.js and chart-tooltip.js don't have any unittests at all.
pie-chart.js has about 2/3rds coverage and 50% branch coverage.

Change-Id: Ibf3667b0d4d0707df7b092053c43bcd70d07bc25
Partial-Bug: 1435869

added_lines: def update_container(self, container_ref, user_name=None): """Attempt to update a container (which is an invalid operation) Update (HTTP PUT) is not supported against a container resource, so issuing this call should fail. :param container_ref: Reference of the container to be updated :param user_name: The user name used to update the container :return: Response of the update. """ resp = self.client.put(container_ref, user_name=user_name) return resp

leveraging new functionality from occ.

commit_message:
Introduce upper-constraints to requirements.

This is thoroughly documented in the cross project spec 'requirements
management'. In short though, we manage the exact versions we test
with as a change controlled thing and use async processes to push
convergence and keep up to date.

Change-Id: I5fc747646ae9371f0cc085b1e15af45951d20152

commit_message:
Fixes the non-existent exception NoTokenLookupException

Found that troveclient.client raises a non-existent exception,
resolved the same.

Change-Id: I678cf6c1d82aca07fc950032bc6d5de55f8f52b8
Closes-Bug: #1454783

commit_message:
Allow --insecure to override --os-cacert

Change --insecure to ignore the --os-cacert setting.  This is a change
from before where OSC followed the requests pattern of cacert taking
priority.

This logic is also introduced in os-client-config 1.3.0; we
do not require that release yet so it is duplicated here for now.
That change will come with the upcoming global options refactor.

Closes-Bug: #1447784
Change-Id: Iaa6d499ed0929c00a56dcd92a2017487c702774a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/17/188417/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(dtroyer): --insecure is the non-default condition that # overrides any verify setting in clouds.yaml # so check it first, then fall back to any verify # setting provided. self.verify = not self.cloud.config.get( 'insecure', not self.cloud.config.get('verify', True), ) # NOTE(dtroyer): Per bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1447784 # --insecure now overrides any --os-cacert setting, # where before --insecure was ignored if --os-cacert # was set. if self.verify and self.cloud.cacert: self.verify = self.cloud.cacert
deleted_lines: cacert = self.cloud.cacert if cacert: self.verify = cacert else: self.verify = not self.cloud.config.get('insecure', False) self.verify = self.cloud.config.get('verify', self.verify)

commit_message:
Run creating of Sahara templates only on primary controller

Sahara templates creating is running on every controller node - it's
absolutely wrong. It should be run only on primary-controller node.

commit_message:
Don't support deprecated drivers' vendor_passthru

In Kilo, a common mechanism was added that all drivers use for exposing
their vendor methods. Drivers' own implementations of vendor_passthru()
method was deprecated, and backwards compatibility was maintained for any
out-of-tree drivers that still implemented their own version of the
vendor_passthru() method.

This change removes support for that backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: Ib63b0bcc703ad4ea6aeba4e4471baf22e2e1a7fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/30/188530/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # NOTE(lucasagomes): Before the vendor_passthru() method was # a self-contained method and each driver implemented their own # version of it, now we have a common mechanism that drivers # should use to expose their vendor methods. If a driver still # have their own vendor_passthru() method we call it to be # backward compat. This code should be removed once L opens. if hasattr(vendor_iface, 'vendor_passthru'): LOG.warning(_LW("Drivers implementing their own version " "of vendor_passthru() has been deprecated. " "Please update the code to use the " "@passthru decorator.")) vendor_iface.validate(task, method=driver_method, **info) task.spawn_after(self._spawn_worker, vendor_iface.vendor_passthru, task, method=driver_method, **info) # NodeVendorPassthru was always async return (None, True)

commit_message:
Remove dependency on oslo.utils (replace with small util code)

Since this is meant to be a leaf dependency for openstack it should
not depend on any other openstack packages, so to make this happen
just have a really tiny ``_utils.py`` code module that contains the needed
functionality used from ``oslo.utils`` (at a later date we may be able
to better handle this).

Change-Id: Ifbca049f5a56f31ab1ae596d80a5c30ff8438805

subject: replace rpc_response_timeout use in rabbit driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-03 19:57:08.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/a0b33a46598499c47ac90eba26f27bff4eab991c', 'message': 'replace rpc_response_timeout use in rabbit driver

The rabbit driver was using the rpc_response_timeout configuration
option as a reconnect timeout value, even though the option was defined
only in oslo_messaging.client and was not always being registered before
being accessed. An earlier patch fixed this by registering the option
here in the driver, too, but that breaks several levels of
abstraction. This changes the driver to define a new option with the
same default value, so that the driver is only using options it defines
itself. It also removes the old hacky fix.

Closes-bug: #1461182

Change-Id: Ia96c815d157219e12a10d94b87b0156503369a6b
'}]
commit_message:
replace rpc_response_timeout use in rabbit driver

The rabbit driver was using the rpc_response_timeout configuration
option as a reconnect timeout value, even though the option was defined
only in oslo_messaging.client and was not always being registered before
being accessed. An earlier patch fixed this by registering the option
here in the driver, too, but that breaks several levels of
abstraction. This changes the driver to define a new option with the
same default value, so that the driver is only using options it defines
itself. It also removes the old hacky fix.

Closes-bug: #1461182

Change-Id: Ia96c815d157219e12a10d94b87b0156503369a6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/63/188163/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('kombu_reconnect_timeout', # NOTE(dhellmann): We want this to be similar to # rpc_response_timeout, but we can't use # "$rpc_response_timeout" as a default because that # option may not have been defined by the time this # option is accessed. Instead, document the intent in # the help text for this option and provide a separate # literal default value. default=60, help='How long to wait before considering a reconnect ' 'attempt to have failed. This value should not be ' 'longer than rpc_response_timeout.'), duration = ( timeout if timeout is not None else self.conf.oslo_messaging_rabbit.kombu_reconnect_timeout )
deleted_lines: from oslo_messaging.rpc import client as rpc_client # FIXME(dhellmann): This is a hack to make sure the option # we're about to use is registered. Since we're not going # through a Client object here, it won't be registered by # Client.__init__. We should do this more cleanly. self.conf.register_opts(rpc_client._client_opts) duration = (timeout if timeout is not None else self.conf.rpc_response_timeout)

commit_message:
Run check-storyboard-js-integration on real nodes

The job was misconfured as if it were a job template to run on
a parameterized "{node}" rather than actual node names.  Correct
it.

Change-Id: Ie33577ee34feefb8602004d90d6c79d7a2c0e470

added_lines: Futurist* A ``futurist.GreenThreadPoolExecutor`` using `eventlet`_ green thread pools. It provides a standard `executor`_ API/interface and it also gathers execution statistics. * A ``futurist.ProcessPoolExecutor`` derivative that gathers execution statistics. * A ``futurist.SynchronousExecutor`` that **doesn't** run concurrently. commit_message:
Rename futures.py -> _futures.py and expose at futurist module

Instead of having to expose the underlying futures impl and the
code and modules associated just expose at the futurist module level
the classes we want to expose (to avoid having to expose any inner
module details that people should not be using).

Change-Id: Ib53052a2df5c673b6e0f6956398b56a4f99f93c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/futurist refs/changes/82/187382/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Claim messages and delete messages

Implmenting claim messages and delete messages necessitated a refactoring
of the proxy interfaces. They were ugly and cumbersome. The information
was pushed into the objects. This comes at the expense of a bit of
validation when creating messages but it's minor.

The new design is more in tune with the hypermedia nature of the Message
Service API. Before I was fighting against it, trying to parse out ids.
That's a recipe for brittle code. Much better to make use of the hrefs as
they're intended to be used.

Change-Id: Ib14632a2a05539eae060771f46e0a313a652903f

commit_message:
Create object files directly in datadir.

Prior to this change, all object files were initially created in
the "tmp" directory which was created directly under the disk
mount point (e.g. /srv/node/r0/tmp). XFS creates files in the
same allocation group as its parent directory. As a result all files
were getting created in the same allocation group and performance
of XFS dropped significantly very quickly.

This commit fixes the above problem by doing the following:
1. Creates a temperory file with the extension ".objtmp" directly in
   the final data directory.
2. Creates a symlink to this file under the "tmp" directory.
3. If the PUT succeeds, the objtmp file is renamed to .data as earlier
   and the symlink is deleted.
4. If the PUT fails, the object replicator now deletes the symlinks
   as well as any stale .objtmp files.
5. Stale .objtmp files are also deleted while cleaning up the hash
   directory.

Closes-Bug: #1450656.
Change-Id: I5912f8f523c116c528b216f34f5b7b713c3e6d19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/83/180883/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def remove_failed_obj_tmp(files, hsh_path, reclaim_age=ONE_WEEK): """ Deletes .objtmp files that were left behind by failed PUTs. :param files: Directory listing of the hash directory :param hsh_path: object hash path :param reclaim_age: age in seconds at which to remove tombstones :returns: list of files remaining in the directory """ for filename in list(files): if not filename.endswith('.objtmp'): continue if (time.time() - os.path.getctime(filename)) > reclaim_age: remove_file(join(hsh_path, filename)) files.remove(filename) return files files = remove_failed_obj_tmp(files, hsh_path)def get_symlink_path(path=None, tmpdir=None): """ Computes the symlink path that should be created for a given file path in tmpdir. """ if not path: return md5 = hashlib.md5() md5.update(path) link_path = os.path.join(tmpdir, md5.hexdigest()) return link_path # Delete the symlink created to the temporary object. objSymlink = get_symlink_path(self._tmppath, self._diskfile._tmpdir) try: os.unlink(objSymlink) except OSError: self._logger.exception('Error removing symlink: %s' %objSymlink) if not exists(self._datadir): mkdirs(self._datadir) try: fd, tmppath = mkstemp(suffix=".objtmp", dir=self._datadir) # Create a symlink for this file in _tmpdir. This symlink # is used to clean-up .objtmp files in case the PUT request # fails. os.symlink(tmppath, get_symlink_path(tmppath, self._tmpdir)) elif ext == '.objtmp': discard() def is_reclaimable_objtmp(filename): return time.time() - time.ctime(os.path.getctime(filename)) > reclaim_age if '.objtmp' in results and is_reclaimable_objtmp(results['.objtmp']): results.setdefault('obsolete', {}).append(results.pop('.objtmp'))

commit_message:
IBP: force signature wiping by lvcreate by '--yes'

By default lvcreate tries to wipe signatures on allocated volume.
If it finds signature, then it will ask for user confirmation to
wipe.
In order to prevent appearing of this interactive prompt '--yes'
should be passed to lvcreate call.

Change-Id: I62bd09d5907e38a457b840acc08a28b487002107
Related-Bug: #1462009

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/63/107363/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This document is aimed to provide a step-by-step guide for manual installation of Trove with an existing OpenStack environment for development purposes. This document does not cover OpenStack setup. This document does not cover production-specific moments like high availability or security. This document does not cover all possible configurations. It only provides one possible way to get things running. - Environment with freshly installed Ubuntu 12.04 LTS to run Trove services. This will be referred to as "local PC" - Running OpenStack environment. All of OS's services must be accessible directly from the environment - AMQP service (ZeroMQ, RabbitMQ, QPid) - MySQL database for Trove's internal needs, accessible from the environment - Certain OpenStack services must be accessible via network from virtual machines: - Swift - VMs must be accessible from local environment for development/debugging purposes The following information about existing environment is required:: - Keystone host and port(s) - OpenStack administrator's username, tenant and password - Nova compute URL - Cinder URL - Swift URL - AMPQ connection credentials (RabbitMQ URL: user Id, password; etc.) - Trove's backend (MySQL, PostgreSQLetc) connection string Install required packages ------------------------- Python settings --------------- Some packages in Ubuntu repo are outdated, so install their latest version from sources:: ## Use latest setuptools # wget https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/s/setuptools/setuptools-{{latest}}.tar.gz # tar xfvz setuptools-{{latest}}.tar.gz # cd setuptools-{{latest}} ## Use latest pip # wget https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/p/pip/pip-{{latest}}.tar.gz # tar xfvz pip-{{latest}}.tar.gz # cd pip-{{latest}} Note '--user' above -- we installed packages in user's home dir, in $HOME/.local/bin, so we need to add it to path:: Install virtualenv, create environment and activate it::Get Trove's sources from git::First install required python packages::Resolve dependency conflicts (if there are any) Install Trove itself::Install Pythob-Troveclient::We'll need several OS clients as well:: # pip install python-keystoneclient # pip install python-novaclient Create a tenant 'trove' and users 'regular_trove_user' and 'admin_trove_user' with password 'trove' to be used with Trove. These values are not required to all be 'trove'; you can instead choose your own values for the names, tenants, and passwords:: --os-tenant-name <OpenStackAdminTenant> --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0 --os-tenant-name <OpenStackAdminTenant> --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0 user-create --name regular_trove_user --pass trove --tenant trove --os-tenant-name <OpenStackAdminTenant> --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0 user-role-add --name admin_trove_user --tenant trove --role admin --os-tenant-name <OpenStackAdminTenant> --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0 --os-tenant-name <OpenStackAdminTenant> --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0 --publicurl 'http://<LocalEnvironmentPublicIP>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' --adminurl 'http://<LocalEnvironmentPublicIP>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' --internalurl 'http://<LocalEnvironmentPublicIP>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' There are several configuration files for Trove:: - api-paste.ini and trove.conf -- for trove-api service - trove-taskmanager.conf -- for trove-taskmanager service - trove-guestagent.conf -- for trove-guestagent service - trove-conductor.conf -- for trove-conductor service - <datastore_manager>.cloudinit -- userdata for VMs Cloudinit scripts for different datastore types like mysql/percona, cassandra, mongodb, redis, couchbase.Vanilla image As the source image for trove instances, we will use a cloudinit-enabled vanilla Ubuntu image::Convert the downloaded image into uncompressed qcow2:: Upload the converted image into Glance:: # glance --os-username trove --os-password trove --os-tenant-name trove --os-auth-url http://<KeystoneIP>:35357/v2.0At this step please remember image ID, or: # export IMAGEID=<glance_image_id> ------------------ Cloud-init scripts ------------------ Cloud-init location place <datastore_manager>.cloudinit at /etc/trove/cloudinit Cloud-init content each cloudinit script should contain: - database package installation; - python installation; - trove installation; - adding simple script that will launch trove-guestagent with appropriate configuration files that would be injected into the provisioned VM; - trove-guestagent service registration (); - adding trove-guestagent to operating system upstart script Note: File injection happens before cloud-init gets executed ------------------------------------ Custom images with Trove code inside ------------------------------------ TO BE ADDED Create trove database scheme: - Log into backend (MySQL, PostgreSQL, etc.); - Create table called `trove`; - Grand access to certain user from certain host to it; - Compose connection string. Example: mysql://root:e1a2c042c828d3566d0a@localhost/trove ----------------------- Initialize the database ----------------------- # trove-manage --config-file=${TROVE_CONF_PATH}/trove.conf db_recreate ${TROVE_PATH}/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/ --------------------------- Setup Trove with Datastores --------------------------- # export DATASTORE_TYPE="mysql" # available options: cassandra, mysql, mongodb, redis, couchbase # export DATASTORE_VERSION="5.5" # available options: for cassandra 2.0.x, for mysql: 5.x, for mongodb: 2.x.x, etc. # export PACKAGES="mysql-server=5.5" # available options: cassandra=2.0.9, mongodb=2.0.4, etc # trove-manage datastore_version_update "${DATASTORE_TYPE}" "${DATSTORE_VERSION}" "${DATASTORE_TYPE}" ${IMAGEID} "${PACKAGES}" 1 # trove-manage datastore_update "${DATASTORE_TYPE}" "${DATASTORE_VERSION}" ========= Run trove-api:: # trove-api --config-file=${TROVE_CONF_DIR}/trove-api.conf & Run trove-taskmanager:: # trove-taskmanager --config-file=${TROVE_CONF_DIR}/trove-taskamanger.conf & Run trove-conductor:: # trove-conductor --config-file=${TROVE_CONF_DIR}/trove-conductor.conf & Trove interaction ================= ------------ Keystonerc:: ------------ You need to build `keystonerc` file that contains to simplify auth process while using Trove client:: export OS_TENANT_NAME=trove # Tenant name export OS_USERNAME=regular_trove_user export OS_PASSWORD=trove export OS_AUTH_URL="http://<KeystoneIP>:5000/v2.0/" export OS_AUTH_STRATEGY=keystone ------------------------------ Try executing a trove commands ------------------------------ You need to do next:: # commit_message:
Log with info instead of warn when collector not configured

Users who are debugging unrelated issues are frequently interpreting
logged warnings as an indication that os-collect-config is misconfigured
when the warning is actually harmless.

This change uses info instead of warn for this logging.

Change-Id: I28e0fb37b603364eea72cdc5299a29259489b820
Closes-Bug: #1437952

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-03 20:19:21.000000000', 'files': ['mcagents/erase_node.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/1b8588b6ea2d2e7f492255ba14eac5ebd466a731', 'message': 'Update erase_node deletion process

When mcollective is launched via Upstart, the current implementation
of the filesystem erase code is not being executed as part of the
SIGTERM handler that is called when we attempt to SIGTERM all
processes. This change pulls the majority of the code we use to
erase a system out of a child thread into the main agent action. This
change leaves the reboot in a child process and SIGTERM handler so

commit_message:
Update erase_node deletion process

When mcollective is launched via Upstart, the current implementation
of the filesystem erase code is not being executed as part of the
SIGTERM handler that is called when we attempt to SIGTERM all
processes. This change pulls the majority of the code we use to
erase a system out of a child thread into the main agent action. This
change leaves the reboot in a child process and SIGTERM handler so
that astute will get the response for the erase_node command and will
mark it complete. An added benefit of this change is that the debug
messages are now returned back to astute and show up in the astute.log
where previously they were being silently discared.

Change-Id: Ib9ee7db0a4d872ea5d1485ec036940f12b0d251e
Closes-Bug: 1461074

commit_message:
Bump keystoneclient version

The openstackclient team is preparing a new release of OSC, and
it will depend on new code that is only available as of
keystoneclient 1.6.0. This will help in migrating devstack to
be fully identity v3 compatible.

Change-Id: I347cae0efe89369f706be0db1bb3b5bca41d3c5f

commit_message:
Move CapturedSubprocess fixture to base

This fixture is going to be useful in other places as well.

Change-Id: Ib321db7f9c1a4656fd9dcd583f5893ef9bee3ca7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/22/187822/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from testtools import contentclass CapturedSubprocess(fixtures.Fixture): """Run a process and capture its output. :attr stdout: The output (a string). :attr stderr: The standard error (a string). :attr returncode: The return code of the process. Note that stdout and stderr are decoded from the bytestrings subprocess returns using error=replace. """ def __init__(self, label, *args, **kwargs): """Create a CapturedSubprocess. :param label: A label for the subprocess in the test log. E.g. 'foo'. :param *args: The *args to pass to Popen. :param **kwargs: The **kwargs to pass to Popen. """ super(CapturedSubprocess, self).__init__() self.label = label self.args = args self.kwargs = kwargs self.kwargs['stderr'] = subprocess.PIPE self.kwargs['stdin'] = subprocess.PIPE self.kwargs['stdout'] = subprocess.PIPE def setUp(self): super(CapturedSubprocess, self).setUp() proc = subprocess.Popen(*self.args, **self.kwargs) out, err = proc.communicate() self.out = out.decode('utf-8', 'replace') self.err = err.decode('utf-8', 'replace') self.addDetail(self.label + '-stdout', content.text_content(self.out)) self.addDetail(self.label + '-stderr', content.text_content(self.err)) self.returncode = proc.returncode if proc.returncode: raise AssertionError('Failed process %s' % proc.returncode) self.addCleanup(delattr, self, 'out') self.addCleanup(delattr, self, 'err') self.addCleanup(delattr, self, 'returncode') for stream_content in streams: print(stream_content)

commit_message:
Add 'to_dict' operation to Resource class

The added 'to_dict()' operation will expose the internal dict of a
Resource object. Users can use this Python dict exposed for further
processing, e.g. create pretty-table on command line, feed fields
extracted to downstream services or tools. The current implementation
filters out the HEADERS in the object.

Change-Id: Ic7b6fb5e6e18311243e537fd76025fcebf7e2ede
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/42/186242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def attrs(self): return self._attrs @property

commit_message:
Fix cfg.py checks list_config_files if it is empty

Raise exception ConfigFilesInDirectoryNotFound if config files
are not found in the requested directory.

Change-Id: Ic6e28db99a702018237a41578d83e5d1afcfe98c
Closes-Bug: #1423169

subject: Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-29 16:06:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/bc506a60b885b4abdb54d81267cb03a71140d647', 'message': 'Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP

W/o this fix, when the management interface on the controller node
running a Swift proxy is down, HAProxy would fail to update
its backend status at the storage network.

This is a problem as we want swift backends not able to connect the
swift endpoint via the management VIP to be marked down. Othewise,
responces time for any requested swift commands would be drastically
longer. Simple httpcheck option cannot resolve this because the swift
healthcheck reports OK, if conntacted via the storage network.

In order to fix this, simple healthcheck script is implemented.
This script is running as xinetid service at TCP port 49001 and
checks the Swift healthcheck report via given swift admin endpoint with
connection timeout 5 seconds and reports an HTTP 200 OK, if the result is OK.
If the result was not OK or the endpoint was not reachable,
it would report an HTTP 503 Error. Expected failover time will
be around 30 seconds.

DocImpact: Reference architecture, swift failover.

Closes-bug: #1459772

Change-Id: I55a35b45257763a20f33bd47cb5c57de53558ccf
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-29 16:23:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/06c297623a50867c7bafea3cc84b366d8af34054', 'message': 'Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP

running a Swift proxy is down, HAProxy would fail to update

swift endpoint via the management VIP to be marked down. Othewise,
responces time for any requested swift commands would be drastically
longer. Simple httpcheck option cannot resolve this because the swift
healthcheck reports OK, if conntacted via the storage network.

In order to fix this, simple healthcheck script is implemented.
This script is running as xinetid service at TCP port 49001 and
checks the Swift healthcheck report via given swift admin endpoint with
connection timeout 5 seconds and reports an HTTP 200 OK, if the result is OK.
If the result was not OK or the endpoint was not reachable,
it would report an HTTP 503 Error. Expected failover time will
be around 30 seconds.

DocImpact: Reference architecture, swift failover.

Closes-bug: #1459772

Change-Id: I55a35b45257763a20f33bd47cb5c57de53558ccf
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-06-01 08:02:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/d7e2d79e0b100f83f05d367c299eab79f4370da9', 'message': 'Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP

W/o this fix, when the management interface on the controller node
running a Swift proxy is down, HAProxy would fail to update
its backend status at the storage network.

This is a problem as we want swift backends not able to connect the
swift endpoint via the management VIP to be marked down. Othewise,
responces time for any requested swift commands would be drastically
longer. Simple httpcheck option cannot resolve this because the swift
healthcheck reports OK, if conntacted via the storage network.

In order to fix this, simple healthcheck script is implemented.
This script is running as HTTP xinetid service at TCP port 49001 and
checks the node under check for the:
a) management VIP is pingable via ICMP (by 3 packets)
b) Swift endpoint is reachable by TCP-connect via the local storage address
within 5 seconds connection timeout
c) Swift healthcheck report via the local storage address endpoint is OK

Reports an HTTP 200 OK, if all of the results are OK.
Otherwise, it would report an HTTP 503 Error.
Expected Swift node control plane failover time will be around 30 seconds.
Swift data plane is not affected.

DocImpact: Reference architecture, swift failover.

Closes-bug: #1459772

Change-Id: I55a35b45257763a20f33bd47cb5c57de53558ccf
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP

W/o this fix, when the management interface on the controller node
running a Swift proxy is down, HAProxy would fail to update
its backend status at the storage network.

This is a problem as we want swift backends not able to connect the
swift endpoint via the management VIP to be marked down. Othewise,
responces time for any requested swift commands would be drastically
longer. Simple httpcheck option cannot resolve this because the swift
healthcheck reports OK, if conntacted via the storage network.

In order to fix this, simple healthcheck script is implemented.
This script is running as HTTP xinetid service at TCP port 49001 and
is accessible only from the localhost, 240.0.0.2, and storage plus
management networks. The service verifies the node under check for the:
a) management VIP is pingable via ICMP (by 3 packets)
b) Swift endpoint is reachable by TCP-connect via the local storage address
within 5 seconds connection timeout
c) Swift healthcheck report via the local storage address endpoint is OK

Reports an HTTP 200 OK, if all of the results are OK.
Otherwise, it would report an HTTP 503 Error.
Expected Swift node control plane failover time will be around 30 seconds.
Swift data plane is not affected.

DocImpact: Reference architecture, swift failover.

Closes-bug: #1459772
Related-bug: #1460623

Change-Id: I55a35b45257763a20f33bd47cb5c57de53558ccf
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Pin pyngus version as python-qpid-proton is not in pypi

check-requirements-integration-dsvm is failing with
the following error:

Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement python-qpid-proton<0.10,>=0.9

the latest released version of python-qpid-proton is 0.8.1 at the moment.

Change-Id: I880cffbe003a27e9caba3695e39e39e3bd9b1fcc
(cherry picked from commit 6aa6ddb129b521e1ddbdc203fef557174f1f3b63)

commit_message:
Angular API Unit Tests

Contains tests for API services.  There are currently few of these, so
these are meant to establish a good baseline.  Since many services are
cookie-cutter, the tests often establish a similar structured pattern.

Change-Id: Ice0dd49e61b0c828b502ec7632534732f934ae76
Partial-Bug: 1435869
Closes-Bug: 1449648

added_lines: /* * (c) Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. * * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. * You may obtain a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and * limitations under the License. */ (function() { 'use strict'; fdescribe('Keystone API', function() { var service, apiService, toastService; // This way tests the explicit calls. Doesn't call out specific values // in quite the same way as above. function testCall(name, method, url, item, err, input) { var errObj = {error: angular.noop}; spyOn(apiService, method).and.returnValue(errObj); spyOn(errObj, 'error'); service[name](input); expect(apiService[method]).toHaveBeenCalledWith(url, item); var innerFunc = errObj.error.calls.argsFor(0)[0]; expect(innerFunc).toBeDefined(); spyOn(toastService, 'add'); innerFunc(); expect(toastService.add).toHaveBeenCalledWith('error', err); } beforeEach(module('hz.api')); beforeEach(module(function($provide) { apiService = { get: angular.noop, post: angular.noop, patch: angular.noop, delete: angular.noop }; toastService = { add: angular.noop }; $provide.value('apiService', apiService); $provide.value('toastService', toastService); })); beforeEach(inject(function(keystoneAPI) { service = keystoneAPI; })); it('defines the service', function() { expect(service).toBeDefined(); }); var tests = { // Name // method, url, item passed, message, test input getUsers: ['get', '/api/keystone/users/', {}, 'Unable to retrieve users.'], createUser: ['post', '/api/keystone/users/', {name: "Matt"}, 'Unable to create the user.', {name: "Matt"} ], deleteUsers: ['delete', '/api/keystone/users/', [1,2,3], 'Unable to delete the users.', [1,2,3] ], }; // Iterate through the defined tests and apply as Jasmine specs. angular.forEach(tests, function(params, name) { it('defines the ' + name + ' call properly', function() { testCall.apply(this, [name].concat(params)); }); }); }); })();

On implementation of the Unified Job Interface Map story, the
JobExecutionArguments table proved fairly useless. As the
JobExecution object is frozen by the time it gets to the edp

commit_message:
Removing JobExecutionArgument Table

On implementation of the Unified Job Interface Map story, the
JobExecutionArguments table proved fairly useless. As the
JobExecution object is frozen by the time it gets to the edp
engine, the job_configs json must be updated, and thus no real
record-keeping purpose is served. Removing it for simplicity.

Change-Id: I010290e8c52b016dfa2f4d7563038bd7407563e5
Describes: blueprint unified-job-interface-map
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/47/188047/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: error. This field will not be returned on a GET of a job execution object; instead, the final, merged configuration will be returned.
deleted_lines: A new table will also need to be created for storage of execution fields, described by: :: CREATE TABLE job_execution_arguments ( id VARCHAR(36) NOT NULL, execution_id VARCHAR(36) NOT NULL, argument_id INT NOT NULL, value TEXT NOT NULL, # ex: 'org.openstack.sahara.examples.WordCount' created_at DATETIME, PRIMARY KEY (id), FOREIGN KEY (execution_id) REFERENCES job_executions(id) ON DELETE CASCADE, FOREIGN KEY (argument_id) REFERENCES job_interface_arguments(id) ON DELETE CASCADE ); This table will have a uniqueness constraint on (execution_id, argument_id). error. This field will also be represented in all GET methods of the Job Execution resource.

commit_message:
Add Nova scenario to boot multiple servers in one request

The performance profile of, e.g., creating 10 VMs in a single request
is often very, very different from creating 10 VMs in 10 requests, and
the difference only grows with the number of VMs. This adds a scenario
to boot an arbitrary number of servers with a single request, which
can be compared to boot_and_delete_server, which boots them one server
per request.

Change-Id: I8cb5d6a4f27cce228b83d6a869ed75c505dd6626

added_lines: @mock.patch("rally.benchmark.scenarios.nova.servers.NovaServers.clients") def test_boot_and_delete_multiple_servers(self, mock_nova_clients): mock_nova_clients.return_value = fakes.FakeNovaClient() scenario = servers.NovaServers() scenario._boot_servers = mock.Mock() scenario._delete_all_servers = mock.Mock() scenario.sleep_between = mock.Mock() scenario.boot_and_delete_multiple_servers("img", "flavor", count=15, min_sleep=10, max_sleep=20, fakearg="fakearg") scenario._boot_servers.assert_called_once_with(mock.ANY, "img", "flavor", 1, instances_amount=15, fakearg="fakearg") scenario.sleep_between.assert_called_once_with(10, 20) scenario._delete_all_servers.assert_called_once_with(force=False)

commit_message:
More verbose exception when ssh fails

When run deployment create on top of ExistingServers provider,
it's useful to know which host-user-password combination failed.

Change-Id: Ie885375f69502e7dcda257265a8c0c9d785d3ca7

Support all_tenants search_opts for neutron

Add support for the all_tenants search option when 
listing security group with neutron as the backend

commit_message:
Moved common deprecation code into _DeprecatedBase class

A lot of private code inside @deprecated is not specific to deprecating
a callable, and it will be useful for reuse when we introduce
@deprecated_parameters decorator to deprecate specific parameters, not
the whole callable.

Related-Bug: #1461043
Change-Id: I440f39e2033300f0641b0dbf24ed87533893c141
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/29/187529/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abc@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class _DeprecatedBase(object): # NOTE(morganfainberg): Bexar is used for unit test purposes, it is # expected we maintain a gap between Bexar and Folsom in this list. BEXAR = 'B' FOLSOM = 'F' GRIZZLY = 'G' HAVANA = 'H' ICEHOUSE = 'I' JUNO = 'J' KILO = 'K' LIBERTY = 'L' _RELEASES = { # NOTE(morganfainberg): Bexar is used for unit test purposes, it is # expected we maintain a gap between Bexar and Folsom in this list. 'B': 'Bexar', 'F': 'Folsom', 'G': 'Grizzly', 'H': 'Havana', 'I': 'Icehouse', 'J': 'Juno', 'K': 'Kilo', 'L': 'Liberty', } def __init__(self, as_of, in_favor_of=None, remove_in=2): self.as_of = as_of self.in_favor_of = in_favor_of self.remove_in = remove_in def _build_message(self, what): details = dict(what=what, as_of=self._RELEASES[self.as_of], remove_in=self._get_safe_to_remove_release(self.as_of)) if self.in_favor_of: details['in_favor_of'] = self.in_favor_of if self.remove_in is not None and self.remove_in > 0: msg = _deprecated_msg_with_alternative else: # There are no plans to remove this function, but it is # now deprecated. msg = _deprecated_msg_with_alternative_no_removal else: if self.remove_in is not None and self.remove_in > 0: msg = _deprecated_msg_no_alternative else: # There are no plans to remove this function, but it is # now deprecated. msg = _deprecated_msg_with_no_alternative_no_removal return msg, details def _get_safe_to_remove_release(self, release): # TODO(dstanek): this method will have to be reimplemented once # when we get to the X release because once we get to the Y # release, what is Y+2? remove_in = self.remove_in if remove_in is None: remove_in = 0 new_release = chr(ord(release) + remove_in) if new_release in self._RELEASES: return self._RELEASES[new_release] else: return new_release class deprecated(_DeprecatedBase): super(deprecated, self).__init__(as_of, in_favor_of, remove_in) msg, details = self._build_message(self.what)
deleted_lines: class deprecated(object): # NOTE(morganfainberg): Bexar is used for unit test purposes, it is # expected we maintain a gap between Bexar and Folsom in this list. BEXAR = 'B' FOLSOM = 'F' GRIZZLY = 'G' HAVANA = 'H' ICEHOUSE = 'I' JUNO = 'J' KILO = 'K' LIBERTY = 'L' _RELEASES = { # NOTE(morganfainberg): Bexar is used for unit test purposes, it is # expected we maintain a gap between Bexar and Folsom in this list. 'B': 'Bexar', 'F': 'Folsom', 'G': 'Grizzly', 'H': 'Havana', 'I': 'Icehouse', 'J': 'Juno', 'K': 'Kilo', 'L': 'Liberty', } self.as_of = as_of self.in_favor_of = in_favor_of self.remove_in = remove_in msg, details = self._build_message() def _get_safe_to_remove_release(self, release): # TODO(dstanek): this method will have to be reimplemented once # when we get to the X release because once we get to the Y # release, what is Y+2? remove_in = self.remove_in if remove_in is None: remove_in = 0 new_release = chr(ord(release) + remove_in) if new_release in self._RELEASES: return self._RELEASES[new_release] else: return new_release def _build_message(self): details = dict(what=self.what, as_of=self._RELEASES[self.as_of], remove_in=self._get_safe_to_remove_release(self.as_of)) if self.in_favor_of: details['in_favor_of'] = self.in_favor_of if self.remove_in is not None and self.remove_in > 0: msg = _deprecated_msg_with_alternative else: # There are no plans to remove this function, but it is # now deprecated. msg = _deprecated_msg_with_alternative_no_removal else: if self.remove_in is not None and self.remove_in > 0: msg = _deprecated_msg_no_alternative else: # There are no plans to remove this function, but it is # now deprecated. msg = _deprecated_msg_with_no_alternative_no_removal return msg, details

Move deprecation messages out of @deprecated decorator

They will be later reused for @deprecated_parameters decorator.

Related-Bug: #1461043
Change-Id: Idf7663afcab5f4759887c72c1f2dcba1eba56c1d

added_lines: @test.attr(type=["gate", ]) def test_extend_share(self): new_size = self.share['size'] + 1 # extend share and wait for active status self.shares_client.extend_share(self.share['id'], new_size) self.shares_client.wait_for_share_status(self.share['id'], 'available') # check state and new size share = self.shares_client.get_share(self.share['id']) self.assertEqual(new_size, share['size'])

subject: Enable exclusive tenant external network access
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-28 10:01:37.000000000', 'files': ['etc/neutron.conf', 'neutron/common/config.py', 'neutron/db/external_net_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/423d9aff0ccc8413be8ad9fbf6c27427138c41ad', 'message': "Enable exclusive tenant external network access

Currently all tenants can access all external networks. Currently there is
no way to enable opertaors or admins the ability to provide exclusive tenant
access to external networks.

We add a configuration variable that enables admins to provide the service as
follows:
1. If an external network is marked as 'shared' then it can be seen and used by
   all tenants
2. When an admin creates an external network, they can use the tenant-id for the
   creation. This will enasure that only the tenant can view and use that external
   network.

The above is enabled by the configuration variable 'exclusive_external_networks'

This is by default False to ensure that the existing support is maintained.

WIP

Change-Id: I93901752f87846907874ecce7aa830099c363c0a
"}]
commit_message:
Enable exclusive tenant external network access

Currently all tenants can access all external networks. Currently there is
no way to enable opertaors or admins the ability to provide exclusive tenant
access to external networks.

We add a configuration variable that enables admins to provide the service as
follows:
1. If an external network is marked as 'shared' then it can be seen and used by
   all tenants
2. When an admin creates an external network, they can use the tenant-id for the
   creation. This will enasure that only the tenant can view and use that external
   network.

The above is enabled by the configuration variable 'exclusive_external_networks'

This is by default False to ensure that the existing support is maintained.

WIP

Change-Id: I93901752f87846907874ecce7aa830099c363c0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/38/186338/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfg if cfg.CONF.exclusive_external_networks: query = query.outerjoin(ExternalNetwork, ((original_model.shared is True) | (original_model.tenant_id == context.tenant_id)) & (original_model.id == ExternalNetwork.network_id)) else: query = query.outerjoin(ExternalNetwork, (original_model.id == ExternalNetwork.network_id))

commit_message:
Do not automatically target bugs for stable releases

Stable releases should not include all existing closed bugs, so when we
see that the tag is going into a stable branch skip that step and
encourage the user to do the work by hand.

Change-Id: I0bf3df1ea3c49c962eafa00cab797e9dd9c7b6b3

commit_message:
Add "scheduler_use_baremetal_filters" option in nova conf for ironic

This attribute decides whether to use baremetal_scheduler_default_filters or not.
Set the ironic default attributes for True case.

Change-Id: I2c58707140a1e54fb8fdd7627d23aa23f1a236ea
Closes-Bug: #1444860

commit_message:
WIP: Add check for use of unicode type instead of six.text_type

Change-Id: I1080b081428cb5eabb5542fe525ed8057cae1d90
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/37/186637/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: UNICODE_CLASS_USAGE = re.compile("\bunicode\(.*\)\b") @core.flake8ext @core.off_by_default def hacking_no_unicode_class(logical_line, noqa): r"""Check for Python 2 usage of unicode(). Examples: Okay: unicode = u'A unicode string' H239: unicode('my string') Okay: unicode_as_a_service = 'https://uaas:9090/' """ if noqa: return if UNICODE_CLASS_USAGE.search(logical_line): yield 0, ("H239: the unicode type was removed in Python 3, use " "six.text_type instead")

commit_message:
Sync swift backup files to secondary nodes

This fix syncs swift backups files so it is possible
to replace any controller containing builder files

Look into
http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/recover-ring-builder-file.html

Change-Id: I06acfa52cf4c396b36530714e964a7e2eb7a32b0
Closes-bug: #1461619

commit_message:
New-style page for Liberty-style tracking

Introduce changes as agreed for Liberty release cycle tracking:

- Move the "completed features" to the top of the page
- Move "tracked work in progress" to the bottom
- Use series goal (instead of milestone + priority-set) as the base
  inclusion criteria
- Do not consider absence of milestone target as an error anymore
- Update default sorts for the tables

Change-Id: Icb578845f204c3bb829ea5228827819da698db52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releasestatus refs/changes/02/188402/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: if bp.milestone: if not bp.milestone.is_active: pastbps.add(bp) else: if (bp.implementation_status == 'Implemented' or bp.priority not in ('Undefined', 'Not')): activebps.add(bp)

commit_message:
Switch to using ostestr for subunit-trace

The subunit-trace module has been moved into the os-testr package.
This decouples the nominally independent module from the rest of
tempest-lib which should enable wider usage. However, since some
packages are depending on tempest-lib to use os-testr at this point
we add it to the requirements.txt file instead of test-requirements
so that those consumers won't be broken when this is release.

Additionally, os-testr includes a testr wrapper, ostestr, which
replaces the pretty_tox.sh script and is used to run unit tests.

Depends-On: Ia399c65e62c2306c9a2d082c6219fcb030b5946b
Change-Id: Iafbfa92a91b945b75aaa1f684594c903c8f6f700

#!/usr/bin/env python # Copyright 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # Copyright 2014 Samsung Electronics # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Trace a subunit stream in reasonable detail and high accuracy.""" import argparse import datetime import functools import os import re import sys import subunit import testtools DAY_SECONDS = 60 * 60 * 24 FAILS = [] RESULTS = {} def total_seconds(timedelta): # NOTE(mtreinish): This method is built-in to the timedelta class in # python >= 2.7 it is here to enable it's use on older versions return ((timedelta.days * DAY_SECONDS + timedelta.seconds) * 10 ** 6 + timedelta.microseconds) / 10 ** 6 def cleanup_test_name(name, strip_tags=True, strip_scenarios=False): """Clean up the test name for display. By default we strip out the tags in the test because they don't help us in identifying the test that is run to it's result. Make it possible to strip out the testscenarios information (not to be confused with tempest scenarios) however that's often needed to indentify generated negative tests. """ if strip_tags: tags_start = name.find('[') tags_end = name.find(']') if tags_start > 0 and tags_end > tags_start: newname = name[:tags_start] newname += name[tags_end + 1:] name = newname if strip_scenarios: tags_start = name.find('(') tags_end = name.find(')') if tags_start > 0 and tags_end > tags_start: newname = name[:tags_start] newname += name[tags_end + 1:] name = newname return name def get_duration(timestamps): start, end = timestamps if not start or not end: duration = '' else: delta = end - start duration = '%d.%06ds' % ( delta.days * DAY_SECONDS + delta.seconds, delta.microseconds) return duration def find_worker(test): """Get the worker number. If there are no workers because we aren't in a concurrent environment, assume the worker number is 0. """ for tag in test['tags']: if tag.startswith('worker-'): return int(tag[7:]) return 0 # Print out stdout/stderr if it exists, always def print_attachments(stream, test, all_channels=False): """Print out subunit attachments. Print out subunit attachments that contain content. This runs in 2 modes, one for successes where we print out just stdout and stderr, and an override that dumps all the attachments. """ channels = ('stdout', 'stderr') for name, detail in test['details'].items(): # NOTE(sdague): the subunit names are a little crazy, and actually # are in the form pythonlogging:'' (with the colon and quotes) name = name.split(':')[0] if detail.content_type.type == 'test': detail.content_type.type = 'text' if (all_channels or name in channels) and detail.as_text(): title = "Captured %s:" % name stream.write("
%s
%s
" % (title, ('~' * len(title)))) # indent attachment lines 4 spaces to make them visually # offset for line in detail.as_text().split('
'): stream.write(" %s
" % line) def show_outcome(stream, test, print_failures=False, failonly=False): global RESULTS status = test['status'] # TODO(sdague): ask lifeless why on this? if status == 'exists': return worker = find_worker(test) name = cleanup_test_name(test['id']) duration = get_duration(test['timestamps']) if worker not in RESULTS: RESULTS[worker] = [] RESULTS[worker].append(test) # don't count the end of the return code as a fail if name == 'process-returncode': return if status == 'fail': FAILS.append(test) stream.write('{%s} %s [%s] ... FAILED
' % ( worker, name, duration)) if not print_failures: print_attachments(stream, test, all_channels=True) elif not failonly: if status == 'success': stream.write('{%s} %s [%s] ... ok
' % ( worker, name, duration)) print_attachments(stream, test) elif status == 'skip': stream.write('{%s} %s ... SKIPPED: %s
' % ( worker, name, test['details']['reason'].as_text())) else: stream.write('{%s} %s [%s] ... %s
' % ( worker, name, duration, test['status'])) if not print_failures: print_attachments(stream, test, all_channels=True) stream.flush() def print_fails(stream): """Print summary failure report. Currently unused, however there remains debate on inline vs. at end reporting, so leave the utility function for later use. """ if not FAILS: return stream.write("
==============================
") stream.write("Failed %s tests - output below:" % len(FAILS)) stream.write("
==============================
") for f in FAILS: stream.write("
%s
" % f['id']) stream.write("%s
" % ('-' * len(f['id']))) print_attachments(stream, f, all_channels=True) stream.write('
') def count_tests(key, value): count = 0 for k, v in RESULTS.items(): for item in v: if key in item: if re.search(value, item[key]): count += 1 return count def run_time(): runtime = 0.0 for k, v in RESULTS.items(): for test in v: runtime += float(get_duration(test['timestamps']).strip('s')) return runtime def worker_stats(worker): tests = RESULTS[worker] num_tests = len(tests) delta = tests[-1]['timestamps'][1] - tests[0]['timestamps'][0] return num_tests, delta def print_summary(stream, elapsed_time): stream.write("
======
Totals
======
") stream.write("Ran: %s tests in %.4f sec.
" % ( count_tests('status', '.*'), total_seconds(elapsed_time))) stream.write(" - Passed: %s
" % count_tests('status', '^success$')) stream.write(" - Skipped: %s
" % count_tests('status', '^skip$')) stream.write(" - Expected Fail: %s
" % count_tests('status', '^xfail$')) stream.write(" - Unexpected Success: %s
" % count_tests('status', '^uxsuccess$')) stream.write(" - Failed: %s
" % count_tests('status', '^fail$')) stream.write("Sum of execute time for each test: %.4f sec.
" % run_time()) # we could have no results, especially as we filter out the process-codes if RESULTS: stream.write("
==============
Worker Balance
==============
") for w in range(max(RESULTS.keys()) + 1): if w not in RESULTS: stream.write( " - WARNING: missing Worker %s! " "Race in testr accounting.
" % w) else: num, time = worker_stats(w) stream.write(" - Worker %s (%s tests) => %ss
" % (w, num, time)) def parse_args(): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser() parser.add_argument('--no-failure-debug', '-n', action='store_true', dest='print_failures', help='Disable printing failure ' 'debug information in realtime') parser.add_argument('--fails', '-f', action='store_true', dest='post_fails', help='Print failure debug ' 'information after the stream is proccesed') parser.add_argument('--failonly', action='store_true', dest='failonly', help="Don't print success items", default=( os.environ.get('TRACE_FAILONLY', False) is not False)) return parser.parse_args() def main(): args = parse_args() stream = subunit.ByteStreamToStreamResult( sys.stdin, non_subunit_name='stdout') outcomes = testtools.StreamToDict( functools.partial(show_outcome, sys.stdout, print_failures=args.print_failures, failonly=args.failonly)) summary = testtools.StreamSummary() result = testtools.CopyStreamResult([outcomes, summary]) result = testtools.StreamResultRouter(result) cat = subunit.test_results.CatFiles(sys.stdout) result.add_rule(cat, 'test_id', test_id=None) start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow() result.startTestRun() try: stream.run(result) finally: result.stopTestRun() stop_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow() elapsed_time = stop_time - start_time if count_tests('status', '.*') == 0: print("The test run didn't actually run any tests") exit(1) if args.post_fails: print_fails(sys.stdout) print_summary(sys.stdout, elapsed_time) exit(0 if summary.wasSuccessful() else 1) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

docs: separate design docs from general docs

The 'data model' info is design notes for the OVN integration.  Create
a new section of the docs that separates design notes from general
docs because I have some more things to add to this section.

commit_message:
Use correct rbd pool for nova compute

The libvirt option "images_rbd_pool" must refer to the pool for
instances instead of the pool for glance.

Change-Id: Ib384be4e4ee293118c427562d57e01c8de65fdd8

commit_message:
Fixing execution-update API

 * Fixed handling wrong using execution-update
 * Fixed session hanging in case incorrect using execution update API:
     in case of exception neither commit_tx nor rollback_tx has not
     been invoked -> session acquired semaphore but didn't release it.
   Note: it is related only to sqlite (used in unit tests).

Closes-Bug: #1449557

Change-Id: Ic8874b2d498167cac1a88f6d138e8ac0e1d9a67f

commit_message:
Restart netfilter-persistent instead of iptables-persistent

iptables-persistent has merged into netfilter-persitent as a plugin and
/etc/init.d/iptables-persitent is no longer offered on new debians.
This calls the newer variant when it is found and falls back to the old when
it is not.

Change-Id: Ibfc4c0286636633c2b1823aae5885ee6325fec2d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/astara-appliance refs/changes/91/188191/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os Reload firewall rules via [netfilter/iptables]-persistent Note that at some point iptables-persistent merged into netfilter-persistent as a plugin, so use that instead if it is available _init = '/etc/init.d/%s-persistent' if os.path.isfile(_init % 'netfilter'): init = _init % 'netfilter' else: init = _init % 'iptables' [init, 'restart'],

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Add logic to pass sg and sg-rules to ODL (cont.)

This gerrit makes further changes in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/178325/ to address
issues with translation of security groups from the
newly introduced callback.

Change-Id: Iaaca2e02b4b23bc7e359f9392092ab6c035ece5a
